'''Michael Shackleford''', (May 23, 1965 in [[Pasadena, California|Pasadena]], [[California]], United States), also known as "The Wizard of Odds" – a title taken from [[Donald Angelini]],<ref name="ThePOGG">{{cite web |url=http://www.thepogg.com/thepogg-interviews-michael-shackleford-the-wizard-of-odds/ |title=ThePOGG Interviews – Michael Shackleford – The Wizard of Odds |date=1 November 2012  |author=ThePOGG }}</ref> is [[Americans|American]] [[mathematician]] and an [[actuary]], best known for his professional analysis of the [[Mathematical finance|mathematics]] of the [[casino games]]. He is also an [[Adjunct professor|adjunct]] professor of [[Actuary|actuarial science]] and mathematics at the [[University of Nevada, Las Vegas]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.livescience.com/10446-wizard-odds-math-beat-casinos.html |title='Wizard of Odds' Uses Math To Beat the Casinos |date=21 January 2011  |author=Clara Moskowitz  }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.professional-poker.com/interviews/michael-schackleford/index.htm |title=Interview with Michael Shackleford a.k.a. "The Wizard of Odds }}</ref> He became interested in the mathematics of gambling at a young age, specifically after reading [[John Scarne]]'s Guide to Casino Gambling.<ref name="ThePOGG"/>

Today Shackleford is best known for his websites, The Wizard of Odds and The Wizard of Vegas, which contain analyses and strategies for hundreds of casino games. He received a great deal of attention in 2002 shortly after moving to Las Vegas when he published a paper where he released rankings of [[slot machine]] payout percentages, widely considered secretive or unavailable, to show which Las Vegas casinos set their nickel machines with the best and worst payouts.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/cgi-bin/printable.cgi?/lvrj_home/2002/May-19-Sun-2002/business/18686053.html 
|title=Actuary Releases Ranking of Las Vegas Slot Machine Payout Percentages|  first=Jeff | last = Simpson |  date=May 19, 2002 |work=Las Vegas Review-Journal (Las Vegas, NV) |accessdate=2009-11-15}}</ref> The Time Out Las Vegas referred to the survey as ''groundbreaking''.<ref>{{cite news 
|title=Time Out Las Vegas (5th edition)
|publisher=Time Out Guides 
|page=54 
|accessdate=2011-04-14
|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=R0XKUxrdbEsC&lpg=PA54&ots=n15BQn33n_&dq=nickel%20slots%20shackleford&pg=PA54#v=onepage&q&f=false
}}</ref> This paper was referenced by [[Palms Casino Resort]] to advertise their competitive payouts.<ref name="ThePOGG"/>

The Wizard sites were sold on September 19, 2014 for $2.35 million. Purchased by the LatestCasinoBonuses.com Affiliate Network.<ref>http://calvinayre.com/2014/09/19/business/the-lcb-network-acquires-wizard-of-odds-for-2-35-million/</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://casinoslots.net/news/dec-2014/interview-with-the-wizard-of-odds |title=Exclusive interview with Michael Shackleford about the sale of his websites }}</ref>

Shackleford also analyzes new games for game developers and casinos.  His most notable clients include [[Hilton Hotels Corporation|Hilton]], [[Realtime Gaming]], [[Playtech]], and [[Shuffle Master]].  He is the author of ''Gambling 102: The Best Strategies for All Casino Games'' (Huntington Press, 2005).  Previously, he was an Adjunct Professor of Casino Math at the [[University of Nevada, Las Vegas]] and a contributing editor to ''Casino Player'' magazine.

Michael Shackleford has been known to bring media attention to unfair gambling practices, such as case #2008-7136L before the state Gaming Control Board, against the Stratosphere Casino for failing to pay a sportsbet.<ref>{{cite web |title=Stratosphere’s refusal to honor expired ticket gives sports books another black eye |date= May 16, 2008 |publisher=Las Vegas Sun |author=Jeff Haney
|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2008/may/16/jeff-haney-says-stratospheres-refusal-honor-expire/}}</ref> Another example is his detailed investigation into allegations of cheating by Absolute Poker after they were brought to his attention by an anonymous source September 24, 2007.<ref>{{cite web
|title=Absolute Poker Investigation 
|url=http://wizardofodds.com/software/absolutepoker.html
|author=Michael Shackleford
|date= Jan 15, 2008
}}</ref>

Shackleford is periodically consulted on gambling issues outside of Nevada. In 2010 Pittsburgh Live requested a consult on whether the gaming companies in Pennsylvania would tighten their blackjack rules.<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/ae/gambling/s_710165.html  
|title='Wizard' predicts state will tighten blackjack rules 
|author=Mark Gruetze
|date=November 19, 2010}}</ref>

Every year, professional gambler, Max Rubin holds the famed Blackjack Ball, a secret and invitation-only event, where the winner is given the title of “The Best Gambler in the World.”  Rubin’s love for the game led to the creation of the Blackjack tournament where participants are quizzed with gambling trivia and mathematical questions plus a second series of tests where their skills are put to the test (card counting, signaling, etc.). The 2011 winner was Michael Shackleford<ref>{{cite web
|title=Blackjack Ball 2011 Celebrates the Secret Blackjack society 
|url=http://beat.bodog.com/casino/blackjack-ball-2011-celebrates-the-secret-blackjack-society-48353.html
|date= Jan 22, 2011
|author=Maverick
}}</ref> where he beat [[Anthony Curtis (writer)|Anthony Curtis]] to take the title.<ref name="ThePOGG"/>

Before changing careers, Shackleford worked as a [[claims adjuster]] and later as an actuary for the United States [[Social Security Administration]] from 1992 until 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.casino.org/blog/mike-shackleford-wizard-odds-interview/|title=Mike Shackleford Wizard of Odds interview |  first=Justin | last = Taro |date=2014-06-16}}</ref> His main responsibility there was estimating short-term costs and benefits of Social Security law changes. But, he was best known for researching the most popular baby names for each year since 1880.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ssa.gov/OACT/babynames/background.html|title=Background information for popular names|date=2009-04-03|work=Social Security Administration|accessdate=2009-11-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2002/02/12/news_pf/Business/Actually__it_s_one_of.shtml|title= Actually, it's one of the best jobs in the country.  Actuaries are in growing demand as businesses seek help in assessing risk across a wider playing field. |last=Nealy-Brown|first=J.|date=February 12, 2002 |work=St. Petersburg Times|accessdate=2009-11-15}}</ref> The results of this research have been published in many books, newspapers, and magazines, and the Social Security Administration now officially publishes a new list every year of the previous year's most popular names, along with all the previous years' names.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ssa.gov/OACT/babynames/|title=Popular Baby Names|work=Social Security Administration|accessdate=2009-11-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2003/07/06/magazine/where-have-all-the-lisas-gone.html|title=Where Have All the Lisas Gone?|last=Orenstein |first=Peggy |date=July 6, 2003|work=The New York Times|accessdate=2009-11-15}}</ref>

Shackleford's interest in a broader variety of mathematics topics is shown by his collection of recreational math puzzles and problems. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://mathproblems.info |title=MathProblems.info by Michael Shackleford, A.S.A |date=2 August 2014  |author=Michael Shackleford  }}</ref>

Shackleford resides in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]] with his wife and three children.
